semantic_title: Conditions Diagnosed During Admission But Present Before Admission
section_path: Present on Admission Guidelines > Assigning the POA Indicator > Conditions diagnosed during the admission but clearly present before admission

content.full_text: Assign 'Y' for conditions diagnosed during the admission that were clearly present but not diagnosed until after admission occurred. Diagnoses subsequently confirmed after admission are considered present on admission if at the time of admission they are documented as suspected, possible, rule out, differential diagnosis, or constitute an underlying cause of a symptom that is present at the time of admission. (Evidence: pg no: 118, L29-L30)
content.summary: Conditions diagnosed after admission but clearly present beforehand should receive Y indicator, including suspected or rule-out diagnoses (Evidence: pg no: 118, L29-L30)
key_concepts: Post-admission diagnosis of pre-existing condition (Evidence: pg no: 118, L29)
Suspected diagnoses at admission (Evidence: pg no: 118, L30)
Rule out diagnoses (Evidence: pg no: 118, L30)
Underlying cause of admission symptoms (Evidence: pg no: 118, L30)

detailed_rules.rule_text: Assign Y for conditions diagnosed during admission that were clearly present before admission (Evidence: pg no: 118, L29)
detailed_rules.explanation: When a condition is diagnosed after admission but clinical evidence shows it existed at admission, assign Y indicator (Evidence: pg no: 118, L29-L30)
common_applications: Conditions requiring test results for confirmation

detailed_rules.rule_text: Assign Y for suspected, possible, rule out, or differential diagnoses at admission that are later confirmed (Evidence: pg no: 118, L30)
detailed_rules.explanation: Diagnoses documented as suspected or possible at admission that are later confirmed should receive Y indicator (Evidence: pg no: 118, L30)
common_applications: Rule out myocardial infarction later confirmed

workflow_steps: Step 1: Identify when condition was diagnosed
Step 2: Determine if condition was present at admission
Step 3: Check for suspected/rule out documentation at admission
Step 4: If present at admission, assign Y

code_categories_mentioned: All conditions diagnosed after admission but present before

coding_scenarios.scenario: Patient admitted with chest pain, MI confirmed on day 2
coding_scenarios.documentation_example: Admission: Chest pain, rule out MI. Day 2: Troponins elevated, acute MI confirmed
step_by_step: Step 1: Note MI was suspected at admission
Step 2: Confirm MI was later diagnosed
Step 3: Assign Y because condition was suspected at admission

correct_coding.rationale: MI was suspected at admission and later confirmed (Evidence: pg no: 118, L30)

incorrect_coding.rationale: Should not assign N when condition was suspected at admission
incorrect_coding.common_mistake: Focusing on diagnosis timing rather than condition presence

warnings: Focus on condition presence, not diagnosis timing (Evidence: pg no: 118, L29-L30)
best_practices: Review admission documentation for suspected diagnoses (Evidence: pg no: 118, L30)
common_mistakes: Assigning N based on diagnosis timing rather than condition presence (Evidence: pg no: 118, L29-L30)
tips: Look for rule out or suspected language in admission notes (Evidence: pg no: 118, L30)
implementation_notes: Train coders to distinguish diagnosis timing from condition presence
clinical_context: Many conditions require time and testing for definitive diagnosis
